facts.text: For the assessment year 1947-48 the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 142 of 1963 filed a return of her income before the Income-tax Officer, District IV, Calcutta, and the assessment was completed sometime in 1948 as a result whereof tax was payable by her.

On April 2, 1956, the Income-tax Officer served on the appellant in CA No. 142/1963 a notice dated March 19, 1956, under s. 34(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, on the ground of escaped assessment. The date of the notice fell within 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year i.e., March 31, 1948 but it was served beyond 8 years from that date and, therefore, was clearly out of time under the provisions of the said section.

For the assessment year 1947-48 the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1963 was assessed on a total income of Rs. 28,993/- on December 30, 1948, by the Income-tax Officer and the tax thereon amounting to Rs. 4,747-13-0 was deposited on behalf of the appellant in the Reserve Bank of India.

On April 2, 1956, the appellant in CA No. 143/1963 was served with a notice dated March 19, 1956, by the Income-tax Officer purporting to be under s. 34 of the Act on the ground of escaped assessment. The date of the notice fell within 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year, i.e., March 31, 1948 but it was served beyond 8 years from that date and was, therefore, clearly out of time under the provisions of the said section.
The appellants in the two appeals filed two petitions in the High Court of Calcutta under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the said notices and for other appropriate reliefs.
On March 20, 1957, Sinha, J., of the Calcutta High Court issued rules nisi on the said two applications to the Income-tax Officer, the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Union of India.
On September 11, 1958, the said Judge made the rules absolute.
The respondents to the applications preferred appeals from the judgment of Sinha, J., to a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court.
Pending the appeals, on March 12, 1959, s. 34 of the Act was amended by s. 2 of the Amending Act.

After the said amendment the appeals were heard by a Division Bench of the High Court, consisting of Bose, C. J., and G. Mitter, J. Relying upon the said amendment the learned Judges held that the said notices, though served on the appellants after the prescribed time, were saved under s. 4 of the Amending Act. In that view they set aside the orders of Sinha, J., and dismissed the writ petitions.
Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 13, 1961, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders No. 41 and 69 of 1959.

legal_issues.text: The true construction of the provisions of s. 4 of the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1959 (Act No. 1 of 1959), particularly whether notices under s. 34(1)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, dated within but served beyond 8 years from the end of the relevant assessment year are saved by s. 4 notwithstanding being out of time for service.

petitioner_arguments.text: The notices under s. 34(1) of the Act were served on the appellants beyond 8 years from the end of the assessment year and therefore, were barred and that on a true construction of the provisions of s. 4 of the Amending Act, the said notices were not saved thereunder.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 34(1)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; s. 4 of the Amending Act

petitioner_arguments.text: s. 4 of the Amending Act only saves a notice issued after the prescribed time but does not apply to a situation where notice is issued within but served out of time.

respondent_arguments.text: The expression 'issued' means served and that, in any view, it is comprehensive enough to take in the entire process of giving and serving of notice.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 4 of the Amending Act; s. 34(1)(a) of the Act

court_reasoning.text: Rules of construction of fiscal statutes: stringent for charging provisions, ordinary for machinery; s. 4 resuscitates barred claims, so stringent rules apply.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The Amending Act was passed to save validity of notices issued beyond time under s. 34(1)(a).

court_reasoning.text: The crucial word 'issued' in s. 4: no time limit for sending notice under s. 34(1)(a), only for service within 8 years; 'issued' not in narrow sense of sent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial interpretation equates 'issued' with 'served' (CIT v. V. Ghurve; Sri Niwas v. ITO).

court_reasoning.text: Legislative practice and dictionaries treat 'issued' and 'served' interchangeably (General Clauses Act s. 27); wider meaning carries out intention, avoids anomalies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Narrow meaning would defeat purpose in cases where notices sent within time but served after.

court_reasoning.text: s. 4 saves notices, assessments etc. issued beyond prescribed time under pre-1956 s. 34; wider meaning of 'issued' makes section consistent and workable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intention to save validity from attack on ground of time expiry.

holdings.text: The word 'issued' in s. 4 of the Amending Act bears the wider meaning including service; notices served beyond prescribed time are saved.

precedents_cited.relevance: Intention to impose charge must be shown by clear and unambiguous language in taxing statute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Canadian Eagle Oil Co. v. R.
precedents_cited.relevance: In taxing Act, look merely at what is clearly said; no intendment, equity or presumption.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gursahai Saigal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Stringent construction for taxing provisions, ordinary for machinery provisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. C. Prashar v. Vasantsen Dwarkadas
precedents_cited.relevance: s. 4 validates notices under s. 34(1)(a) even issued before April 1, 1956.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay South v. V. Ghurve
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Issued' in proviso to s. 34 equates with 'served' in substantive part.

precedents_cited.case_name: Barras v. Aberdeen Steam Trawling and Fishing Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Subsequent statute uses word with prior judicial interpretation in similar context.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowered ITO to serve notice within 8 years for escaped assessment; time limit for service.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1959 (Act No. 1 of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Saves notices, assessments etc. under s. 34(1)(a) from challenge on ground of time expiry under pre-1956 amendment.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1956 (No. XVIII of 1956)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended s. 34 prior to Amending Act of 1959.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897 (Act X of 1897)
statutes_cited.relevance: Treats 'serve', 'give', 'send' as interchangeable for service by post.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petitions to quash notices.

outcome.summary: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs. The notices under s. 34 are validated by s. 4 of the Amending Act as 'issued' includes service beyond the prescribed time.

key_quotes.text: "In a taxing Act one has to look at what is clearly said. There is no room for any intendment. There is no equity about a tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rule of construction for taxing statutes from Canadian Eagle Oil Co.

key_quotes.text: "The expression 'issued' used in the proviso to sub-section (3) should be equated with the expression 'served' rather than that the expression 'served' used in sub-section (1) should be equated with the expression 'issued'."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From CIT v. V. Ghurve, equating 'issued' with 'served'.

key_quotes.text: "The clear intention of the Legislature is to save the validity of the notice as well as the assessment from an attack on the ground that the notice was given beyond the prescribed period."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on purpose of s. 4.
